symptoms: Pain radiating to left arm or jaw
s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Seek **emergency medical care immediately** for chest pain/shortness of breath.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Seek **emergency medical care immediately (F.A.S.T. signs)**.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult doctor urgently to start/adjust medication. Seek emergency care if blood sugar is very high (ketoacidosis signs).

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Nephrologist as soon as possible** for staging and treatment plan.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Pulmonologist immediately** to start a management plan, especially if breathlessness worsens rapidly.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a doctor **immediately** for diagnosis and testing.

symptoms: Chest pain when breathing or coughing
s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a doctor **immediately** for testing and to start the required antibiotic regimen.

symptoms: Swollen lymph nodes (in neck or groin)
s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult an **Infectious Disease specialist immediately** for testing and to start ART (Antiretroviral Therapy).

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Neurologist** for diagnosis and to initiate symptom management.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Psychiatrist immediately**. Seek **emergency help** if suicidal thoughts are present.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Seek **emergency medical care** if BP $\ge 180/120$ with severe symptoms.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Hepatologist immediately** for management and monitoring.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Seek medical care **immediately**, especially if breathing is difficult or fever is high.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Seek **emergency medical care immediately (call emergency services)**.

symptoms: Sudden or rapid reduction in hearing ability
s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: If **Sudden**: Consult ENT within 72 hours. If Gradual: See ENT/Audiologist within 14 days.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Rheumatologist immediately** to prevent joint damage.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Rheumatologist immediately** for diagnosis and management.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Gastroenterologist immediately** for diagnosis and treatment.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Seek medical care **immediately** to start life-saving insulin therapy.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. (If Acute Angle-Closure). Consult **Ophthalmologist immediately** for vision loss.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: Routine follow-up/supplements.
s3_trigger: If **Sudden**: Consult Retina Specialist immediately. S2 (Dry): Routine follow-up/supplements.

symptoms: Unusual vaginal bleeding (after intercourse or menopause)
s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Gynecologist immediately** for testing (Pap smear, biopsy).

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Seek medical care **immediately** for urgent diagnosis and life-saving treatment.

s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Consult a **Psychiatrist immediately**. Seek **emergency help** if risk of harm is high.

symptoms: Severe pain starting around naval and shifting to lower right abdomen
s1_action: Stop eating/drinking; avoid pain relievers that hide diagnosis.
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Seek **emergency medical care immediately** for sudden, shifting lower right abdominal pain.

symptoms: Signs of severe dehydration (dry mouth, sunken eyes)
s1_action: N/A
s2_action: N/A
s3_trigger: Immediate action required. Seek **emergency medical care immediately** for rapid, severe dehydration.

s1_action: Follow DASH diet, limit sodium, exercise, and take prescribed medicine.
s2_action: Follow up with PCP within 1-3 months to check BP and medication effectiveness.
s3_trigger: If BP $\ge 180/120$ or new severe symptoms (severe headache, chest pain) occur, consult doctor immediately.

symptoms: Chest pain (only if severe plaque buildup)
s1_action: Diet low in saturated fat, high in fiber, regular exercise, and take prescribed medicine.
s2_action: Follow up in 3 months for lipid panel check.
s3_trigger: If IHD or Stroke symptoms (chest pain, numbness) are felt, consult doctor immediately.

s1_action: Calorie-controlled diet, 150 mins exercise/week, manage weight.
s2_action: Consult a Dietitian for a personalized plan. Set weight loss goals.
s3_trigger: If chest pain, severe breathlessness, or Type 2 Diabetes symptoms occur, consult doctor.

symptoms: Mild pain/fullness in upper right abdomen
s1_action: Weight loss (7-10% of body weight), eliminate alcohol/sugar, and follow a healthy diet.
s2_action: Consult a Gastroenterologist for monitoring (FibroScan) and further advice.
s3_trigger: If Jaundice, abdominal swelling (Ascites) occurs, consult doctor immediately.

s1_action: Weight management, low glycemic diet, exercise, and lifestyle changes.
s2_action: Consult a Gynecologist for hormonal/metabolic assessment and medication.
s3_trigger: If heavy and prolonged bleeding occurs, consult doctor immediately.

s1_action: Strict adherence to medication, diet, blood sugar monitoring, and exercise.
s2_action: Routine follow-up with Endocrinologist every 3-6 months.
s3_trigger: If blood sugar is persistently high or low, or Type 1 symptoms occur, consult doctor immediately.

s1_action: Strict adherence to prescribed medication (Levothyroxine) dosage.
s2_action: Consult Endocrinologist every 1-3 months for blood TSH/T4 checks.
s3_trigger: If new or severe symptoms occur (e.g., severe fatigue, altered mental status), consult immediately.

s1_action: Use heat therapy and OTC NSAIDs (Ibuprofen, Naproxen) for pain.
s2_action: Consult a Gynecologist to discuss hormonal/surgical management options.
s3_trigger: Sudden, extremely severe, or unrelenting pelvic pain.

symptoms: Persistent ache or stiffness in joints
s1_action: Use RICE (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation) for flare-ups, low-impact exercise.
s2_action: Consult a Physical Therapist for exercise program or specialist if pain persists.
s3_trigger: Joint becomes hot, red, and swollen rapidly, or severe fever with joint pain.

symptoms: Persistent ache or stiffness in the back
s1_action: Maintain gentle activity, use heat/ice, improve posture, OTC NSAIDs.
s2_action: Consult Physical Therapist for core strengthening and specialized exercises.
s3_trigger: Loss of bladder/bowel control, or sudden severe leg weakness (Emergency).

s1_action: Practice mindfulness, breathing exercises, reduce caffeine and alcohol.
s2_action: Start therapy (CBT) with a Psychologist/Counselor.
s3_trigger: Panic attack that feels like a heart attack, or uncontrollable, paralyzing anxiety.

s1_action: Maintain routine, light physical activity, prioritize sleep, seek social support.
s2_action: Consult a Psychologist/Counselor for therapy and Psychiatrist for medication assessment.
s3_trigger: Self-harm or suicidal thoughts (Seek emergency help immediately).

symptoms: Dull, aching pain around the head
s1_action: Use OTC relievers (Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen), rest, hydrate.
s2_action: Consult PCP if headaches occur $>15$ days/month (chronic TTH).
s3_trigger: Headache accompanied by fever, stiff neck, confusion, or sudden severe onset (Emergency).

symptoms: Usually one side of the head
s1_action: Use OTC relievers early, rest in dark, quiet room, manage triggers.
s2_action: Consult Neurologist for prescription abortive/preventative drugs if attacks are frequent/severe.
s3_trigger: The 'worst headache of your life' (Thunderclap headache - Emergency).

symptoms: Joint pain that worsens with activity
s1_action: Use heat/cold, maintain healthy weight, low-impact exercise, OTC NSAIDs.
s2_action: Consult Physical Therapist/Orthopedic Specialist for long-term management.
s3_trigger: Sudden inability to bear weight on the joint, or severe, unexplained swelling.

symptoms: Often asymptomatic until a fracture occurs
s1_action: Ensure adequate Calcium/Vitamin D, engage in weight-bearing exercise.
s2_action: Consult PCP for DEXA scan and prescription medication (e.g., bisphosphonates).
s3_trigger: Fracture from a minor fall or trauma (Seek urgent orthopedic care).

symptoms: Numbness/tingling in thumb, index, middle fingers
s1_action: Wear wrist splint (especially at night), take frequent breaks, use OTC NSAIDs.
s2_action: Consult Specialist if pain/numbness persists for injections/surgery planning.
s3_trigger: Rapidly worsening hand weakness or loss of muscle at the base of the thumb.

symptoms: Waking up at night to urinate
s1_action: Avoid fluids before bed, limit caffeine/alcohol, scheduled urination.
s2_action: Consult Urologist for diagnosis, symptom severity scoring, and prescribed medication.
s3_trigger: Complete inability to urinate (Acute Urinary Retention - Emergency).

s1_action: Use OTC Antihistamines, Nasal Steroid Sprays, avoid known allergens, saline rinse.
s2_action: Consult Allergist for testing/immunotherapy (allergy shots) if symptoms are severe/chronic.
s3_trigger: Severe difficulty breathing or asthma flare-up.

symptoms: Vitiligo: Loss of skin color in patches
s1_action: Moisturize frequently, use OTC creams (Salicylic Acid/Coal Tar for Psoriasis), avoid triggers.
s2_action: Consult Dermatologist if severe/spreading for prescription topical/systemic treatment.
s3_trigger: If skin lesions become infected, or cover a large percentage of the body rapidly.

s1_action: Take appropriate supplement (Iron with Vitamin C) as per PCP advice. Adjust diet.
s2_action: Consult PCP for blood tests to confirm cause, deficiency type (Iron, B12, Folate), and track levels.
s3_trigger: Severe fatigue/weakness, or chest pain (Seek urgent care).

s1_action: Take prescribed dosage of Vitamin D3 supplements daily, ensure safe sun exposure.
s2_action: Consult PCP for blood test to check levels after 3-6 months to adjust dose.
s3_trigger: None specific, but severe symptoms of hypocalcemia (e.g., muscle cramps) need attention.

s1_action: Always carry and use prescribed rescue inhaler (e.g., Salbutamol) during attacks.
s2_action: Consult doctor for control medication/management plan. Identify and avoid triggers.
s3_trigger: If rescue inhaler is ineffective, or symptoms worsen rapidly (Seek **emergency care**).

s1_action: Implement strict sleep hygiene (routine, dark/cool room). Use OTC aids short-term (Melatonin).
s2_action: Consult Sleep Specialist for CBT-I (Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia) if chronic.
s3_trigger: Worsening daytime function, dependency on sleeping pills.

s1_action: Maintain good oral hygiene; use OTC pain relief (Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen) temporarily.
s2_action: Consult a Dentist **immediately** for a filling or other necessary treatment (e.g., root canal).
s3_trigger: Severe, throbbing, unrelenting tooth pain, or facial swelling (Urgent dental care).

symptoms: Gums that bleed easily when brushing
s1_action: Brush twice and floss daily, use mouthwash.
s2_action: Schedule a professional dental cleaning and check-up.
s3_trigger: Severe, painful gum abscess (Periodontitis) or loose teeth.

s1_action: Follow 20-20-20 rule for screens; use artificial tears for dryness.
s2_action: Consult Optometrist for a comprehensive eye exam and corrective lenses/contacts.
s3_trigger: Sudden, unexplained vision loss or double vision (Emergency).

s1_action: Wear sunglasses, ensure adequate lighting, regular vision checks.
s2_action: Consult Ophthalmologist for monitoring and surgical planning when vision significantly interferes with daily life.
s3_trigger: Sudden, severe vision loss in one or both eyes.

symptoms: Trouble following conversations in noisy places
s1_action: Use ear protection in loud environments, try to face the speaker.
s2_action: Consult Audiologist for a comprehensive hearing test and to discuss hearing aids/amplification.
s3_trigger: Sudden hearing loss (Consult ENT within 72 hours).

s1_action: Apply OTC Topical Antifungal Creams/Powders (e.g., Clotrimazole) 2x daily, keep area dry.
s2_action: Consult Dermatologist if no improvement after 2 weeks or if infection spreads widely.
s3_trigger: Signs of bacterial secondary infection (increased redness, pus, severe pain).

s1_action: Wash gently, use OTC topical treatments (Benzoyl Peroxide, Salicylic Acid), do not pick.
s2_action: Consult Dermatologist if severe/scarring for prescription meds (retinoids, oral antibiotics).
s3_trigger: Acne is rapidly worsening or causing significant psychological distress.

symptoms: Dry, itchy, red patches of skin
Often on hands, neck, inner elbows, knees
Worse in cold or dry weather
s1_action: Moisturize frequently (especially after bathing), avoid triggers, use mild Hydrocortisone (Short-term).
s2_action: Consult Dermatologist if severe or not controlled by OTC treatments for prescription creams.
s3_trigger: Skin becomes infected (pus, increased redness, fever).

symptoms: May affect scalp or body hair
s1_action: Protect exposed scalp from sun, manage stress, use Minoxidil (Rogaine) as discussed with doctor.
s2_action: Consult Dermatologist for diagnosis and potential corticosteroid injections.
s3_trigger: Rapid, total hair loss (Alopecia Totalis/Universalis).

s1_action: Drink plenty of water, use Phenazopyridine (Symptom relief only).
s2_action: Consult PCP **immediately** for prescribed antibiotics (requires urine culture).
s3_trigger: If fever, back/flank pain, nausea/vomiting (Kidney infection - Seek urgent care).

s1_action: Use Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen for pain/fever. Apply warm compress.
s2_action: Consult PCP for diagnosis; may need prescribed antibiotics if bacterial (especially in children).
s3_trigger: Severe pain, swelling behind the ear, or severe dizziness.

symptoms: Sudden pain in muscle/joint after injury
s1_action: Use RICE protocol (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation). Use OTC NSAIDs (Ibuprofen).
s2_action: Consult Physical Therapist if pain persists after 1 week for a rehab plan.
s3_trigger: Inability to bear weight or move the limb at all (May indicate a fracture or severe tear).

symptoms: Cold: Runny nose, sneezing, mild sore throat.
Flu: High fever, severe body aches, fatigue, dry cough.
s1_action: Rest, hydrate, use symptom relief (Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen, decongestants, cough suppressants).
s2_action: Flu: Consult PCP within 48 hours of onset for antiviral medication.
s3_trigger: If severe shortness of breath/chest pain, confusion, or high fever not subsiding (Seek **emergency care**).

s1_action: Use humidifier, fluids, OTC cough medicine/expectorants. Rest.
s2_action: Consult PCP if cough lasts $>3$ weeks or if mucus is green/bloody (may need antibiotics).
s3_trigger: Shortness of breath or high fever (Rule out Pneumonia).

s1_action: Absolute rest; use Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen for fever/pain. Avoid contact sports for 1 month (spleen risk).
s2_action: Consult PCP for diagnosis and supportive care. Fatigue may last weeks.
s3_trigger: Sudden sharp left upper abdominal pain (Splenic rupture - Emergency).

s1_action: Rehydrate with Oral Rehydration Salts (ORS), eat bland foods (BRAT diet). Loperamide use with caution.
s2_action: Consult PCP if symptoms last $>3$ days or if signs of severe dehydration.
s3_trigger: Severe, bloody diarrhea, or signs of extreme dehydration (dizziness, no urination - Emergency).

s1_action: Strict rest, hydration, **avoid all alcohol/Acetaminophen/NSAIDs** (harmful to liver).
s2_action: Consult Specialist for supportive management and monitoring of liver function.
s3_trigger: Signs of hepatic failure (severe confusion, bleeding, severe vomiting - Emergency).

s1_action: Use Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen for symptom relief only. Hydrate.
s2_action: Seek **immediate blood test/treatment** with prescribed antimalarials as directed by doctor.
s3_trigger: If severe symptoms (convulsions, unconsciousness, severe breathing difficulty) seek **emergency care**.

s1_action: Use **Acetaminophen only** (AVOID NSAIDs/Aspirin). Maintain high hydration.
s2_action: Consult doctor **immediately** for monitoring (platelet count) and hydration management.
s3_trigger: If severe abdominal pain, persistent vomiting, bleeding from nose/gums, or cold/clammy skin (Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever - Seek **emergency care**).

symptoms: Fewer than 3 bowel movements per week
s1_action: Increase water/fiber intake, exercise, use OTC fiber supplements, or osmotic laxatives.
s2_action: Consult PCP/Gastroenterologist if chronic, severe, or unresponsive to lifestyle changes.
s3_trigger: Constipation accompanied by severe abdominal pain, vomiting, or blood in the stool (Seek urgent care).

symptoms: Sour or bitter taste in the throat/mouth
s1_action: Avoid trigger foods (spicy, fatty), don't lie down after eating, elevate head of bed. Use Antacids/H2 Blockers.
s2_action: Consult Gastroenterologist if symptoms are daily/severe or not controlled by OTC meds, for prescription PPIs.
s3_trigger: Chest pain accompanied by sweating/shortness of breath (Rule out Cardiac issues - Emergency).

symptoms: Feeling of sickness in the stomach
s1_action: Sip clear liquids (ORS), bland diet. Use OTC antiemetics (Dimenhydrinate).
s2_action: Consult PCP if vomiting persists $>48$ hours or with severe symptoms (fever, blood in vomit).
s3_trigger: Inability to keep liquids down, or vomiting blood (Seek urgent care).

symptoms: Bleeding during bowel movements (bright red blood)
s1_action: Prevent straining (fiber/water), sitz baths, use topical Hemorrhoid creams/suppositories.
s2_action: Consult PCP/Gastroenterologist if bleeding/pain is frequent or severe for banding/surgical options.
s3_trigger: Excessive, persistent bleeding, or severe anal pain.

symptoms: Mild, localized pain in the head
s1_action: Rest, hydrate, OTC relief (Acetaminophen, Ibuprofen, Aspirin).
s2_action: Consult PCP if headaches become more frequent or severe.
s3_trigger: Sudden severe headache, weakness/numbness, fever/neck stiffness.

s1_action: Lozenges, saltwater gargles, warm fluids, pain relief (Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen).
s2_action: Consult PCP if severe, lasts $>5$ days, or for Strep test/prescribed antibiotics.
s3_trigger: Severe difficulty breathing or inability to swallow saliva (Seek urgent care).

symptoms: Ringing, buzzing, or roaring sound in the ears
s1_action: Avoid loud noise, use masking sounds (white noise), manage stress.
s2_action: Consult ENT/Audiologist to find underlying cause and discuss noise therapy/management.
s3_trigger: Sudden onset tinnitus, especially if accompanied by hearing loss or severe vertigo.

symptoms: Vertigo: Sensation of spinning/moving (even when stationary).
s1_action: Sit down immediately, move slowly, avoid sudden position changes. OTC Meclizine (for vertigo).
s2_action: Consult ENT/Neurologist for diagnosis (e.g., BPPV, Meniere's disease).
s3_trigger: If accompanied by severe headache, weakness, slurred speech, chest pain (Seek **emergency care**).

symptoms: Excessive mucus/phlegm buildup in the nose/throat
s1_action: Daily Saline Nasal Sprays/Rinses, humidifier, avoid irritants. OTC decongestants (short-term).
s2_action: Consult ENT to check for underlying allergies, sinus infection, or polyps.
s3_trigger: Fever, severe facial pain, or thick, colored nasal discharge.

s1_action: Elevate the affected limb. Use Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen for symptoms.
s2_action: Consult doctor **immediately** for prescribed antibiotics (requires rapid treatment).
s3_trigger: If spreading rapidly, red streaking, or high fever/vomiting (Seek **emergency care**).

s1_action: Rehydrate with Oral Rehydration Salts (ORS), eat bland diet. Loperamide can be used (use with caution).
s2_action: Consult PCP if lasts $>3$ days, or with fever/blood/signs of dehydration.
s3_trigger: Severe, bloody diarrhea, or signs of extreme dehydration (dizziness, reduced urination - Emergency).

s1_action: Rest, hydration, OTC pain relief.
s2_action: Nasal decongestants, salt water gargle.
s3_trigger: Fever >102Â°F, symptoms >10 days, difficulty breathing.

s1_action: Rest, plenty of fluids, Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen.
s2_action: Antiviral medication (if prescribed early), isolation.
s3_trigger: Shortness of breath, chest pain, confusion, persistent high fever.

s1_action: Hydration, light clothing, Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen.
s2_action: Tepid sponging, monitoring temperature.
s3_trigger: Fever >103Â°F, fever lasting >3 days, severe headache/stiffness.

s1_action: Hydration, lozenges, vaporizers.
s2_action: OTC cough syrups (suppressants/expectorants).
s3_trigger: Coughing up blood, severe chest pain, cough >3 weeks.

s1_action: Lozenges, saltwater gargles, warm fluids, pain relief (Acetaminophen/Ibuprofen).
s2_action: Consult PCP if severe, lasts $>5$ days, or for Strep test/prescribed antibiotics.
s3_trigger: Severe difficulty breathing or inability to swallow saliva (Seek urgent care).

symptoms: Dull or throbbing pain in the head
s1_action: Rest in a dark room, hydration, OTC pain reliever.
s2_action: Identify and avoid triggers (e.g., stress, dehydration).
s3_trigger: Sudden severe headache, weakness/numbness, fever/neck stiffness.

symptoms: Severe, pulsing pain on one side of the head
s1_action: Rest, hydration, specific migraine medication (Triptans).
s2_action: Avoidance of known triggers (food, environment), stress management.
s3_trigger: Sudden change in headache pattern, paralysis/visual loss.

s1_action: Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS), bland diet (BRAT).
s2_action: OTC anti-diarrheal medication (Loperamide - use with caution).
s3_trigger: Dehydration (dry mouth, sunken eyes), blood/mucus in stool, fever.

s1_action: Increase fiber intake, plenty of water, exercise.
s2_action: OTC laxatives or stool softeners (short-term use).
s3_trigger: Severe abdominal pain, inability to pass gas, vomiting.

s1_action: Avoid triggers (spicy/fatty food), eat slowly.
s2_action: Antacids (e.g., Tums) or H2 blockers.
s3_trigger: Blood in stool or vomit, unintentional weight loss, persistent symptoms.

s1_action: Sip clear fluids (ORS), avoid solid food.
s2_action: Bland diet when symptoms ease, anti-nausea medication.
s3_trigger: Inability to keep fluids down for >12 hours, severe abdominal pain, signs of dehydration.

s1_action: Avoid trigger foods, do not lie down immediately after eating.
s2_action: Antacids, Proton Pump Inhibitors (PPIs) - (short term).
s3_trigger: Symptoms resistant to OTC meds, difficulty swallowing (dysphagia).

s1_action: Identify and avoid allergen, OTC antihistamines.
s2_action: Nasal steroid sprays, prescribed allergy medication.
s3_trigger: Anaphylaxis (severe swelling, difficulty breathing).

s1_action: Avoid touching eyes, wash hands frequently, use artificial tears.
s2_action: Antibiotic or antiviral eye drops (depending on the cause).
s3_trigger: Severe eye pain, vision changes, sensitivity to light.

s1_action: OTC cleansers with Salicylic Acid or Benzoyl Peroxide.
s2_action: Topical retinoids, oral antibiotics, hormonal therapy.
s3_trigger: Severe, cystic acne leading to scarring.

s1_action: Rest, heat/cold packs, gentle stretching, OTC pain relief.
s2_action: Physiotherapy, specific exercises.
s3_trigger: Loss of bowel/bladder control, leg weakness, pain following trauma.

s1_action: Rest (RICE), OTC NSAIDs (Ibuprofen).
s2_action: Physiotherapy, targeted exercise, specific diagnosis.
s3_trigger: Acute swelling, inability to bear weight, joint deformity.

symptoms: limited movement near a joint (e.g., ankle)
s1_action: R.I.C.E. (Rest, Ice, Compression, Elevation), OTC pain relief.
s2_action: Immobilization (bandage/splint), physiotherapy after acute phase.
s3_trigger: Inability to bear weight at all, severe deformity.

symptoms: limited movement in a muscle (e.g., hamstring)
s1_action: R.I.C.E., gentle stretching after 48 hours.
s2_action: Gradual return to activity, specific physical therapy.
s3_trigger: Severe pain, muscle tearing/bulging, significant weakness.

s1_action: Good sleep hygiene (fixed schedule, dark room), relaxation techniques.
s2_action: Cognitive Behavioral Therapy for Insomnia (CBT-I), short-term sleep aids.
s3_trigger: Worsening daytime function, dependency on sleeping pills.

s1_action: Deep breathing, meditation, regular exercise, setting boundaries.
s2_action: Counseling/Therapy, anti-anxiety medication (if severe).
s3_trigger: Panic attacks, suicidal thoughts, inability to perform daily tasks.

s1_action: Salt restriction, regular exercise, healthy diet, stress management.
s2_action: Prescription anti-hypertensive medications.
s3_trigger: BP readings consistently $>180/120$, signs of stroke/heart attack.

s1_action: Diet control (low sugar), regular exercise, weight management.
s2_action: Oral medications, insulin therapy (if needed).
s3_trigger: Uncontrolled blood sugar (Hyper/Hypoglycemia), foot ulcers, vision loss.
